Legal_Issue: Whether the jeopardy order issued under s. 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act should be set aside due to insufficient evidence that collection would be jeopardized by delay
Governing_Law: s. 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act
Application_Facts: Taxpayer's instability, asset changes, and operational difficulties
Remedy_Requested: Motion to set aside the jeopardy order
Court_Ruling: Jeopardy order revoked; taxpayer's motion allowed
Defendant_Behavior: No evidence of asset dissipation or intent to evade taxes
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient evidence that tax collection would be jeopardized by delay
Legal_Standard: Reasonable grounds to believe delay would jeopardize collection; burden on Crown to prove beyond a reasonable doubt
Assessment_Factor: Lack of evidence of asset dissipation or evasion intent
Procedural_Issue: Ex parte application for a jeopardy order followed by taxpayer's motion to set it aside
Evidence_Used: Alleged instability, asset changes, operational difficulties
Application_Basis: Risk of non-collection due to delays
Evidence_Assessed: No evidence of asset dissipation or intent to evade
Governing_Rule: Under s. 225.2(2), immediate collection authorized if delay jeopardizes collection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Mere suspicion insufficient; Crown failed to meet burden of proof
Harm_Assessment: Potential harm from premature tax collection without sufficient justification
Cause_Description: Minister's concern over unpaid taxes and risk of non-collection due to delays
Evidence_Handling: Court found no credible evidence supporting jeopardy
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence did not establish reasonable grounds for belief of jeopardy
Decision_Rationale: Mere suspicion inadequate; Crown did not prove jeopardy beyond a reasonable doubt
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of concrete evidence of asset dissipation or evasion
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable grounds supported by evidence meeting the standard of proof beyond a reasonable doubt
